learning_outcomes.description: Analyse electrical engineering problems to determine where computational techniques in matrix algebra, stochastic systems and optimisation theory can be applied.
Interpret the theoretical foundations of matrix algebra, stochastic systems and optimisation theory
Design solutions for electrical engineering problems by applying key algorithms in matrix algebra, stochastic systems and optimisation theory
Implement computational techniques in MATLAB with a high level of proficiency

assessments.task_description:
The assignments will be designed to develop skills in problem solving based on the theory presented in lectures on the first part (optimisation), often using MATLAB.

The tasks in Assignment 1 have been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit the assignment (report and code) via the Blackboard turnitin assignment submission system.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
30/04/2026 6:00 pm

The exam will take place outside of scheduled class time from 6:00 pm to 8:00 pm on 30/4/2026.
assessments.task_description:
This exam will take place outside of scheduled class time (6:00pm - 8:00 pm, 30/04/26) and will cover the Optimisation part. 

The exam will be 90 minutes in duration. This exam will be closed-book and may contain multiple-choice, short-answer, and problem-solving questions.

Multiple-choice assessment is used for less than 50% of the exam.

This assessment task is to be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
There are three parts in this assignment.

In the first part, the assignment questions will be designed to develop skills in problem-solving based on the theory presented in lectures on Optimisation, often using MATLAB.

In the second part, the assignment questions will be designed to develop skills in problem-solving based on the theory presented in lectures on Linear Algebra, often using MATLAB.

In the third part, students must prepare a report and presentation. Presentation details will be provided in the specification of Assignment 2.

 

The tasks in Assignments 2 have been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submit the assignment (report and code) via the Blackboard turnitin assignment submission system.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam covers linear algebra and stochastic processes parts. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Applied classes

This course will offer a weekly 2-hour applied class session from week 2 to week 13. These sessions are timetabled as PRA01. During these sessions, students can receive feedback on the given tasks.
